awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Algae Cultivation Technology for Value Added Co-products from Waste Water Treatment Effluent
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impacts of this Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve reuse of wastewater.  This project advances a new algae reactor to reduce biological nutrient pollution. This will improve health, potential loss of commercial fishing resources, water tourism, and property value decline.  The diversity of products that can be generated from algae cultivation improve the robustness of the global food chain and the security of domestic feedstocks, e.g. high nutrition feeds for livestock and aquaculture and a new source of chemicals and biofuels.  The proposed design for maximum resource efficiency in water and energy enables value extraction from marginal lands.

The proposed project aims to reduce levels of biological nutrient pollutants in the effluent of wastewater treatment facilities—by the development of an industrial scale, algae photobioreactor, designed to operate in a high-volume, continuous flow process.  Anticipated advantages of the new technology are a reduction in capital and operating expense compared to existing nutrient removal methods and the capacity to generate, high-purity, algae coproducts with commercial value.  Research objectives include the following: (1) create a computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model of the reactor under various flow conditions; (2) perform dye tracer experiments in the reactor as validation of the modeling results; (3) install the reactor as part of an integrated nutrient removal system including ultrafiltration, product recycle stream, nutrient sensors and process feedback control; (4) evaluate the nutrient removal capabilities of the system using a live algae culture and effluent from an adjacent wastewater treatment facility; and (5) perform a technoeconomic analysis of the proposed process.  Results of the project will provide a better understanding of the effect of reactor design and operating parameters on the hydraulic and solids residence time distributions, how these influence the waste removal performance of the system, and what design parameters exert the most control over economic feasibility.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to evaluate a new algae photobioreactor for removing biological nutrient pollution from wastewater.  Biological nutrients, which consist of chemicals like nitrates, phosphates, and organic carbon, arise from various sources such as municipal sewage, fertilizer runoff from lawns and fields, animal manure, and wastewater from food and beverage industries.  As a result of nutrient pollution, receiving waters can undergo a surge in microbial populations of algae and bacteria who consume the nutrients for growth.  More than just making slimy water, algae blooms can release harmful toxins while overgrowth of bacteria can lead to low levels of dissolved oxygen within the water.  Ultimately, these conditions can cause to a loss of biodiversity, including large fish kills. Uncontrolled algae growth is even implicated in the rise of invasive carp species, who selectively feed on algal biomass. Consequently, nutrient pollution can have enormous economic impacts, due to loss of commercial fishing, beach closures, lost tourism, reduced real estate values, human medical costs and expensive environmental cleanups. The damages to US freshwaters alone are estimated to be  $2.2 B/year.  In response to this growing problem, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and state agencies have established goals in recent years to improve waterbody health by regulating the discharge of nutrient pollution through stricter water quality standards.  While good for the environment, these policies can be challenging to implement, and the EPA has called for the development of new, more affordable technologies to allow emitters to meet the required water quality standards.

While algae are a big part of the problem, they can also be part of the solution, and Pure Biomass has the technology to make this possible. (www.purebiomass.org)  By cultivating algae in a controlled environment like an algae bioreactor,  wastewater can be stripped of its nutrients, and algae can be harvested from the water before it reenters the environment.  Collected algae biomass can then be sold as a value-added product. The Triangular Prism Algae Reactor (TriPARTM) developed by Pure Biomass is an algae cultivation platform with multiple features designed to streamline algae cultivation and improve operational efficiency. Building on work already completed under a prior NSF SBIR project  (# 1660227), the subsequent project described herein focused on adapting the TriPARTM system for applications in wastewater treatment.  This requires the TriPARTM to cultivate algae in high-volume, continuous flow conditions and to produce effluent with very low levels of phosphorus (< 0.02 mg/L). 

With funding from the NSF, the TriPARTM was retrofitted with additional equipment necessary to simulate wastewater treatment.  Using the experimental system, a six-week trial was performed to study how algae can use energy from the sun to remove phosphate, ammonia, and organic substrates present in simulated wastewater.  In addition, Pure Biomass was able to measure key engineering metrics of the TriPARTM, which are needed by engineers when designing wastewater treatment plants.  Grant funds were also used to develop new hardware and software, which allow the TriPARTM to integrate with other industrial equipment used in wastewater treatment plants.  Finally, a techno-economic analysis (a spreadsheet cost model built on engineering design calculations) was prepared to help predict the economic feasibility of the technology and identify which technical goals will be most beneficial to achieving project success.  While some challenges remain, the project was successful, and future R&D work is already being planned.

If the TriPARTM can be developed into a commercially available wastewater treatment process, municipalities, farms, and industries can use the system to help achieve higher, water quality standards and cleanup their surrounding environment.  Algae biomass produced from the TriPARTM can become a source of sustainable bioproducts with a range of applications from soil amendments, to animal feeds, to biofuels. Beyond treatment of wastewater, the TriPARTM is also suitable for production of high-value algae products, like omega-3 fatty acids, human food, nutraceuticals, and specialty chemicals. Lastly, because the TriPARTM is designed for enhanced energy efficiency, water conservation, and customer affordability, it can be used to extract value from marginal lands and stimulate new economic growth.  Overall, the goal of Pure Biomass is to significantly lower the barrier for algae cultivation, in terms of users' access to innovative technologies and process knowledge and by reducing capital and operating costs associated with algae cultivation.


Last Modified: 09/01/2024
Modified by: Georgiy V Vozhdayev
